name: Oxenfree
description: Oxenfree is a supernatural thriller about a group of friends who unwittingly open a ghostly rift. You are Alex, and you’ve just brought your new stepbrother Jonas to an overnight island party gone horribly wrong.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Intel i3 2.0 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 1GB Shader Model 3.0 Compatible (DirectX 9.0c) DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 3 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0 Compatible
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 8.1 64-bit Processor: Intel i5 2.5 GHz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 460 / Radeon HD 6750 (or higher) DirectX: Version 11 Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 3 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0 Compatible

reviews.review_text: I love this game. Like, I  really  love this game.  The dialogue is organic and the voice acting is excellent - nothing the characters say feels forced or shoehorned in. As for the characters themselves they are well rounded, likable and don’t fall into any of the typical teenager stereotypes - and it’s refreshing, to say the  very  least.  The atmosphere is consistently creepy and oppressive, even during the lighter, more comedic moments - and the soundtrack and visual aesthetic add to it. And when you find yourself alone, you  really  feel alone. It’s hard to properly describe, but you’ll know what I mean the first time you get separated from your friends.  My only complaint is that sometimes your companions will occasionally get stuck either on corners or in the middle of a stairwell, but it’s fixed on transitioning to a new area.  I cannot recommend  Oxenfree  more. This game is fascinating, terrifying and excellently written. If you are on the fence about buying it, I urge you. It’s well worth the price tag.
Well-written, well-designed game made by people who obviously put a lot of love into work they're proud of. Really looking forward to Night School Studio's future projects.

Overall, just a genuinely great game. Of course there were some things that could've been improved, but the characters were amazing, mainly in the sense that for once a game has actual realistic teenagers that aren't walking clichés.  The only really issues I had were that there was no way to see what the controls were, although this was only really an issue at the very start, but still I feel like it would've come in handy, and secondly, movement was a bit dodgy, both in the sense of the speed being very slow and also its a bit awkward when turning corners, although I eventually got over both of those problems.  The story was really good and I enjoyed the fact that there are multiple different endings and all that, although I wish you could see there was a way to rewind like in other choice based games instead of having to start over again.  Overall I'd probably give the game a 9/10 due to it being a really good game, definitely would recommend it. Great start to gaming in 2016.

Oxenfree is a relatively short game that follows the story of a group of friends that find themselves stuck on a mysterious island. You play as Alex, a turquoise haired girl, and her personality is pretty much in your hands. In fact, one of my personal favourite game features, is the possibility to choose from different dialogue options whenever the characters interact with eachother, giving you the chance to alter the final development of the story. This means the game has different endings. Specifically, it provides interchangable facts that eventually mix up with eachother, offering the chance of having a wide amount of combinations for each ending. Basically you could play even 4 times and each time get a different set of combinations.  The style of the game is not too complex but its semplicity makes it cute and enjoyable. The mix between 2D and a slight 3D touch (especially for the characters) is pretty remarkable and gives the whole environment an interesting and good look. The soundtrack might become slightly repetitive at times but it generally flows pretty well in the background and fits quite nicely. I was happily surprised by how good the thriller element is portrayed. The pastel colours and the general cute graphics wouldn't let you think the game could get pretty spooky. I personally had one of the worst jumpscares I've ever experienced in videogames while playing this title. The scary effects are not too elaborated but they are astonishingly well made and when they mix up with the creepy sounds and visual elements they can sure send some chills down your spine. So don't get fooled by the innocent art style, because the thriller part of the story is very well taken care of, too.  Probably the only criticism I can make is that sometimes moving from a location to another can be quite a slow process.   The story can be finished in about 5 hours. If you, like I am, are the kind of player that gets a stroke if they don't get all the collectables in the game, then backtracking and looking for all the itmes will take you some time.  This game is really a little spooky adventure that will keep you entertained and looking for answers. Bonus points for the replay value considering the mutliple endings. A nice lil' ghost story to gift yourself.

A incredible game , from the moment i launched in i was hooked , couldnt put it down till the game was finished , i rarely play a game start to finish in one setting but this game grabs you and doesnt let go . the originalty , charector's and level lay outs and puzzles kept you memorized waiting for what will happen next , it story grasp you by the heart strings and has a few good tugs also .a highly recommended title .

Problably the best supernatural-adventure-game I've ever played. Unlike other games of this style (e.g. Life is Strange), your decisions actually impact the thrilling story and the ending. It even seems like the decisions of other players impact on what you see while playing!  I bought it today, I finished today. This is definitely one of my top spontaneous purchases. You all got my buy recommendation!  Other games this one reminds me: Life is Strange, Alan Wake, Indigo Prophecy (Fahrenheit), Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective

Whoa. Okay.  So even from last year when the game was announced, I was already hyped for it. And I'm happy to say that the final product did not disappoint. This game has such a unique and beautiful art style that I've never seen before, coupled with a minimalistic interface and absolutely SUPERB writing and voice acting. I loved the seamless flow of dialogue between the characters, I was very intrigued by the story and the horror elements. The ending to me at first felt a little...abrupt, but I was left quite thrilled at the plot twist which, even though I saw coming, was still pretty darn cool.  My only gripes were that there were still a few glitches in the game I noticed, where the characters that accompanied me got stuck in some places, which was slightly immersion-breaking. But it's totally understandable since the game literally just dropped. Another little nitpick is I wish there was a fast-travel system for the island, especially in the later stages. Since I'm a completionist, I wanted to explore and find the collectibles, but it was a bit tedious having to manually go everywhere. A fast travel system from point to point would have been handy.  If you're a fan of story-driven, choice-based games like TellTale games or Life is Strange, then this game is without question meant for you. I really enjoyed it and will probably play through it several more times, just to see the different outcomes. And honestly, the story makes it make SENSE to play through the game more than once. If you've finished it, you'll understand why.    UPDATE (June 2, 2016):   There's now a New Game + mode available for this game, and I just finished it. Personally I found it to be a bit underwhelming, since the description promised a lot more than what the game gave, I thought. It had a very interesting new ending, and several new additions that kept me somewhat engaged, but for the most part there really wasn't THAT much added. If you're like me and have previously played at least 5-6 playthroughs of the game already, you'd spend most of it trying to seek out as much new content as possible, and I guess I was disappointed that there wasn't enough of it in my opinion. I was expecting some sort of big expansion or a ton more new dialogue options/scenarios. Still, it was something new.

The way the story is presented starts out as a slice of life story where it consist several teenagers going to an island to relax but ultimately end up in a situation where things go awry. The story is gripping and suspenseful, by the end of it you will be left with a conclusion that will leave you shocked and captivated. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this gem of a game, the soundtrack is catchy and the art style is mesmerizing.

This game was a little slow to get in to because the characters weren't immediately or particularly relatable (to me), but I found myself warming to it over the course of the game as the story unfolded and the plot developed.  The conversation system in this game is quite unique and is one of the game's main strengths. It takes some getting used to because it's unusual: the dialogue options don't wait for you to make a choice. But again I found myself warming to this mechanic because it actually lets you choose to say nothing at all in most situations. A simple concept but quite profound and rare in games where you're usually forced to make a choice even if you don't like any of the options presented. Here you can choose not to respond. A brilliant concept and the developers should be commended for the idea and implementing it well.  What I particularly like is the way the game encourages multiple play-throughs. It's not obvious how to achieve the different endings and outcomes in this game, that is something you have to discover. There's some great ingenuity and game design here and it's underscored by beautiful painterly artwork, an exceptional soundtrack and well-recorded voice acting. The voice acting does feel a little too 'professional' but it's probably better to err that way than the reverse (unprofessional).  There are a few minor annoyances. I experienced a few occasions when dialogue options went off the edge of the screen so you couldn't read them. But overall the game played well, albeit a little slowly. If you don't have patience for narritive-driven games it mightn't be for you but I was impressed by just how much dialogue there is.  I hope this developer can make another game. I quite enjoyed it and I'm definitely interested in any other game they decide to make.

Dis was quite an awesome mystery teen drama affair, with a very neat aesthetic, a fantastic conversation system, along with several choices to influence the ending(s), as well as lots of hidden easter egg mysteries to ponder on.   A highly enjoyable affair all along, it really deserves more attention than what it's currently getting.
I can't believe how good this game is.  Edit: Months later, I still can't.

Oxenfree. I never heard of this game until a few days ago thanks to a Let's Player named Bowlingotter who played 2 hours on a live stream. After seeing that, I began to debate getting it for the $19.99 full price, but something about it drew me to it.   I can say it is money well spent.   What is this game? It's sort of a point and click adventure, with mysteries and spookiness abounding. You play as Alex, a young teenage woman going to an island with some friends, and your new step-brother. As the game progresses you find out the darker secrets of the island, but you also build relationships with your friends, and depending on how you play and how you treat them will determine different things later on, including the various endings you can receive.   How is the gameplay? It's very good. There's a mechanic involving a radio and finding hidden radio stations that is good for those who like to know more about the mystery and also like collectables + achievements. It's all very simple and works very well.  I also would like to praise the voice acting in this game. I was instantly reminded of Life is Strange, another favorite, with the dialogue and level of voice acting here. Everyone does a great job, and there's a LOT of talking, but I never was bored or thought the dialouge was corny; In fact, I wanted more of it. Major kudos to the studio and actors for pulling this off - it could have gone the other way, and never did.  The game also presents the player with various choices much like Telltale games, Until Dawn, or, again, Life is Strange. You get three choices, normally, and this will lead to various responses depending on what you said, and this also allows for a lot of replayability.  The game does, as the description says, revolve around ghosts and it is quite spooky and eerie in parts, specifically relating to the radio, but there's no gore or anything, just spooks and mystery.   I got all the collectables and had a wonderful time. I don't normally spring for a full priced game, especially one I just heard of and is a new IP, but if you're on the fence, I'd say give it a go. If you liked any of the other games I mentioned, I think you'll like this game. It took me about 8 hours, but it's 8 hours of really good and fun content, and some $60 games have that much content, but isn't as good or deep.   As I said, I didn't hear of this game til recently, but I'm so glad I did, and I will be replaying it for sure, not just for the achievements, but the experience, the interaction of characters (which I ended up liking!) and just enjoying the game as a whole, and you should too!

This is how I describe Oxenfree as simple as I could Oxenfree is an Artistic-Walk a lot-Choice Selection and Mind Fucuk game. Not much a game within a game in the game itself but definitely worth the 75% on discounted.

What a Long, Strange Trip It's Been  Oxenfree is a clever, thought-provoking and beautiful journey. Like a lot of great games that have come out recently it's one that is best to experience first hand, at least once, so I won't go too much into detail.  I remember seeing the original reveal-trailer and immediately being captivated by the presentation and mystery, and I was looking forward to playing it for a long time. It was definitely worth the wait, and I enjoyed every single second of it. I know for a fact that it's a trip that I will revisit more times in the future.

Good ideas, bad execution, I usually love story-based, dialog-heavy games like Oxenfree, but holy crap are the characters annoying. I don't know if it was the stilted writing, the amateur voice, or maybe I just hate high schoolers, but I felt nothing for any of the characters and didn't really care what happened to any of them. Ren, esepcially. If he was intended to be extremely obnoxious, then they the writers at least succeeded on that point.  The main draw of the game is the dialog options you can choose for your character that hapes the story and eventual outcome. However, I found myself not choosing any dialog option a lot of the time as the game went on, because I was honestly hoping that it wouldn't lead to more talking. Take that away, and what you're left with is a mediocre ghost story at best. The gameplay was also quit boring. There's a 'puzzle' aspect of the game that involves tuning your radio to specific frequencies, but that was more tedious than illuminating.  I will say Oxenfree had some great art and music.

Really enjoyed this game. If you are a fan of ghost stories check it out.  Also: finally a story-based game that isn't all point-and-click and cut scenes. In fact: spoiler? No cut scenes.  It takes ~5-6 hours to complete the story one time through with no frills, but there is a lot to explore in this game and the endings you can get are often wildly different. If you only play through once then you are missing a lot.  Highly recommended.

Whereas most of these narrative games are content to give the player only trivial cosmetic decisions, with little or no bearing on the story's outcome, Oxenfree provides genuine player choice. That probably shouldnt be remarkable in itself given that there's an established genre of choice-based games, but it is. And for that alone it deserves praise.  But there's more to it than that it meets what should be the genre's basic expectations. The voice-acting, the writing, the art-style, the music and sound design are all nothing less than sublime. Its innovative dialogue system, which doesnt simply freeze time in the manner of LiS or Telltale games, makes for conversations that are uniquely fluid and naturalistic in video games.   This numbers among the few games, which I can count on my fingers, that I feel truly live up to the potential of the medium.
it's beautiful, interesting and characters talk like real people this is so refreshing
Another game that restores my faith in modern gaming.
Very interesting game with a beautiful design, and an interesting story. The main mechanics of the game are simple, but provide a lot of fun with non-important sections.
lively characters, well rounded story and a fantastic flow of conversation.

Oxenfree is an overlooked gem. On the surface, it may appear to be another run-of-the-mill story-driven, decision-based adventure game, but it features great writing & voice acting, an intriguing, insidiously creepy mystery interwoven with a coming-of-age tale, and, without giving too much away, a metaphysical narrative featuring time loops and parallel universes. Much of the gameplay consists of walking from one objective to the next, but the sci-fi elements, well-conceived atmosphere, and fresh dialogue keep these treks from being tedious. The presentation is highly stylized and superb, with the '80s VHS-style visual & audio flourishes being the highlight. Clocking in at around 4 hours, the $20 retail cost may be a bit pricey, though this is certainly worth every penny on sale or in a bundle, especially as it has a New Game + mode which the game strongly encourages through new scenes & dialogue, multiple endings, and differing choice-based consequences you miss in your first playthrough. This is one of the best indie games I've played this decade, and I highly recommend it to those who enjoy sci-fi and horror, decision-based gameplay, or simply engrossing storytelling.
Better than Until Dawn.

Alright, I love story driven games, I like mind bending games (and movies), and this is the most mind bending game since I played Bioshock Infinite. Just finished Oxenfree and I don't really know what to say. This is great. Short, but worth every penny.  You're playing as Alex, you and your friends on your way to an abandoned island and your supposed to party on this island. Nothing out of the ordinary, right? Until you encounter a supernatural rift in a cave, and everything goes to hell. Time loops, persons dying but not really, ghosts communicating through your friends... and a lot more. Don't want to spoil ANYTHING, 'cause this is something you want to experience on your own. Trust me.  Technically... the graphics are gorgeous, the backgrounds are hand drawn and everything seems so real. Soundwise, it has been a long time since I heard such great dialogue between characters, it just feels so genuine and... I'm at a loss for words, really. The music is great and fits so perfectly well in this game world.  What I'm trying to say is - BUY THIS GAME! NOW! PLAY IT! Right now, this is my Game of the Year 2016, without any doubt.

Captivating narrative from the first few minutes in. Reminded me of a 2.5D version of Life is Strange meets Until Dawn. This is an indie game where your choices matter throughout the story and can have repercussions at the end of the game. The game is only around 4-5 hours on average (don't let that discourage you, those are some very glorious few hours), but depending on how much of the dialogue you listen to and other factors it could be longer or shorter. For $5, which is what I just bought it for, the game is literally a steal.

The best Indie game I have played. The atmosphere this game creates is astounding. This is thanks, in part because of the fantastic voice acting and top notch music. The soundtrack and ambient sounds are what make the atmosphere truly somethings special. This game has just the right amount of eeriness, which is further complimented by unique graphics.   This game does have replayablity (multiple endings), however multiple playthroughs are hindered by the slow paced moving mechanics. Moving around the Oxenfree world does take time, but it is time well spent. Listen to the great music and enjoy the landscape.   9/10

Oxenfree is beautiful, well acted in every way and quite enthralling in its story. Sweet, fun and in a lot of ways the most inventive adventure in recent memory (sorry, Firewatch). It is above all, rewarding in a way few games have been of late, be it from the story or the growth of its characters through it. I deeply empathise with them, specially with Alex. I've yet to do a second play-through, but I find myself day in day out thinking about starting one.  Lately, that's the biggest compliment I could give a story-based game.

ITS SO GOOD! The story is great and I played it 4 times for different endings and dialogue. Speaking of which, the dialogue is great! They have a custom system for speech in this game. When a character is speaking, you can interrupt them when you talk. Here's the great thing though, when you interrupt them, they just keep talking after you are done speaking. When they continue speaking they will say 'Anyway' or 'oookay, moving on' and then continue what they said. In other games you wouldn't get to hear their lines.

I rarely feel compelled to write reviews, but I've been hugely impressed by the first couple of hours of Oxenfree.   There's a beautifully, painterly charm to the visuals that instantly draws you into the world. The various characters are really well written, and their dialogue and voice acting gives them great personality.  The various dialogue choices seem pretty meaningless in terms of branching the narrative, but they do allow you to 'own' the protagonist's character. It doesn' sound like much, but it definitely makes you feel more invested versus just allowing the conversations to play out with no interaction.  The game really starts to kick into gear when the supernatural mystery starts to reveal itself. The underlying darkness of the story versus the stunning charm of the visuals makes for a really compelling, 'grown up' experience.  Loving it.

The short version of this could very well be 'Oxenfree is Life is Strange done right.' But I would hope you want more than that.  Overall, this is a charming and well-done game where, in just one playthrough, you realize all the little choices you make each minute. Choices in this game feel like they have weight, even if they may ultimately not. I found myself haunted by my words from the beginning when, really, all I had been trying to do is be friendly and try to help. And, it should be noted, that the option to stay silent is there and I am actually really interested in a totally silent playthrough.  Depending on your view of these games, this will either be a great adventure or a boring walk through a storybook. The game does its best some of the time to alleviate these issues, but shoots itself in the foot in others. So, let me get to the big things that could sway your opinion.  1. Character banter: Let's not beat about the bush, the characters in this game are verbose. You will walk a few steps and we will begin an epic four-part saga into the latest developments of the lot and/or your psyche. You will also frequently listen to the witty banter of the characters, perhaps including yourself. I can see this being a serious draw for some and a serious headache for others. I liked the banter (and actually thought the writing was really well done) but even I was getting a little tied of feeling like I wanted to let these characters talk but still wanting to vocalize my thoughts so we didn't just go off and have more brownies or go try to kill demon people. And there were more than a few times where I felt like I missed something with a character or with a location because I happened to trigger plot progression before one of those actually finished.  2. Map length/navigation: This game is filled with picture-book-style locations that are beautiful to look at and occasionally a nightmare to navigate. My first playthrough was sort of a stumble-on-things-as-you-go run, but I didn't feel that tempted to go seek out secrets/alternative paths mostly because the paths are frustratingly long and we're frustratingly slow. At some point, I think it's legitimate to suggest that the developers made more long, winding paths that I have to do a dance at every hairpin turn because they wanted the game to last longer. I would have spents at least an hour less on this game if there were straight/swooping curved paths instead of zig-zagging paths.  3. Choices: This is inevitable with these sorts of choice-based games where you have to select an option from a list, but choices frequently felt like they took on a life of their own. There's nothing to suggest that 'That's okay' is going to make me say 'That's okay' honestly, sarcastically, or say it honestly, then proceed to insult the person I'm talking to so as to make them think I was saying it sarcastically.
Oxenfree is great. Extra Credits recommendations are always good. I think I should pay it.  ... ... Wait...  :edit:\minimum of two playthroughs is required.

Oxenfree's atmosphere and characters will grab you from the beginning till the end. The game is incredibly well written, and the way they introduce dialogue sections without taking control away from the player makes conversations feel much more organic and engaging. Beautiful art direction and a great soundtrack also help create a special vibe. Funny, intriguing, sad, scary... Oxenfree knows how to be all those things, and it does it with ease and charm.

Oxenfree is a really solid debut for Nighschool studio, i liked the plot and the characters and enjoyed Alex so much. Can i also say that the VO did an amazing job, the dialogue was natural and i didnt feel like i was talking to stupid teenagers, plus the game looks beautiful! I really liked the art direction for this game... Overall not much to say here, it was a lovely experience. I hope we get more quality character driven games like this.   I'd give Oxenfree a solid 9/10. Now go buy and enjoy this game!

So... Oxenfree. What can I say without spoiling it?  It's scary, it's beautiful. It has a story where your choices matter in every way.  It's kind of a point and click adventure in ways, but if that's your thing and you like atmospheric horror, get it. You won't regret it.  It made me write a review, and basically nothing makes me do that these days.

I cannot believe there are so many positive reviews this game. This is not a good game. Its a chore.  Don't get me wrong- The first 20 minutes are cool, It sets up interesting characters, a great setting and the potential for a good story.   But before you know it- you'll be trudging around needlessly oversized area's, tuning your radio everytime you come up to anything of interest or any puzzle (because its the only game mechanic you have), and aching for this game to speed up.  A page on  escapistmagazine.com  states: '[Oxenfree] does feature choices that change the story that unfolds. Relationships become extremely meaningful and making friends, or enemies, will change the course of the game.' This could not be further from the truth! There are 6 different endings, and thats the only thing your choices will eventually effect, .. which little 2 minute ending you see...  The voice acting's really good tho, and there wasn't any of the usual cringy dialogue found in other games with teenagers - so credit to the voice team for holding this game above water.  I really wanted to like this game! but after a few hours of it; I wished I'd never bothered. People always complain about games being too short- but this game should have been condensed into a solid 2 hour experience. Instead- it drags for over 4 hours, that I can never get back.   If you want an emotional game about teenagers- play Gone Home or Life Is Strange -> they are amazing.  This game is NOT a 'Beautiful haunting story that begs to be replayed' (-IGN) Its a slow-walk, radio-tuning simulator. Also, I have no idea why Oxenfree is being prased for how beautiful it apparently looks.  Its visually acceptable. But 'Beautiful'!?? really?..

Spooky without being scary. This is a pretty well written story about a group of teenagers caught in some weird supernatural scenario.  Pros: + Good voice actors + Well written + Clever story + Satisfying ending + Great graphics + Great dialogue choices. I rarely found myself wishing there were more choices  Cons: - Windows only, despite being a Unity game - Not enough save points causing you to reply tons of dialogue again if you're not a 1-sitting player - Takes forever to get around. I found myself not getting 100% only because it would take too long to explore fully  Didn't try Wine or streaming this time around.  tl;dr: Great game, give it all of your money!
Basically a 2.5d Telltale game. Buy it
This game is very very cool.

Oxenfree is a very interesting game. I would go so far as to say it is a rare gem in the gaming world. The premise is that you and a few friends are on an island enjoying time together and exploring. You stumble upon a cave and that is when things start getting crazy.   For me Oxenfree represents nice and simply, how to do a good story and how to fill a small world with interesting lore and locations. The gameplay is simple without anything being too demanding yet is entertaining in what it offers. Early on your are introduced to a game mechanic which is crucial throughout the game.   In terms of horror, I saw a review which said that this game was the love child of Life is Strange and Stranger Things. The latter part is most certainly true, it ramps up tension without doing anything like a jump scare. The introduction of parts of the story add interesting layers of tension and twists, for the sake of a spoiler free review I shall tease you with that a lone and not go into anymore detail.   Lastly and perhaps most memorable is that this game deals with some very deep ideas and themes. Ideas of death, the afterlife, time, parallel worlds and decisions are all discussed in great detail and the addition of choice matters is a very pleasant decision. The way you interact with your friends and the world around you creates relationships, closer friends, enemies, tensions, danger and many other things.   I shant go into anymore detail for this review as I would suggest buying this game. However buy it when it is on sale as great value for money when it is £4 or so.

A really pleasant game with sci-fi/supernatural elements that never terrifies but rather tells a story of friendship and the complexities of human interaction . The writing and voice acting are absolutely top notch; believable, humorous and compelling. It's a short experience (my playthrough was approx 4 hours) and although there are multiple endings I don't feel the need to immediately go back and achievement hunt...my initial playthrough was satisfying and the ending felt right - bittersweet in some respects and deserved in all. A true gem of a game with an idiosyncratic art style, amazing soundtrack and great storytelling.
Fantastic story and voice acting. Bought it for $5 and it was definitely worth it. Maybe not $20 since it's so short.

For the record I’m not the type of person who writes review willfully, SO! Hear me out.  I’m on the 7th timeline here (yes, that’s how intriguing this game is) and I haven’t got bored with it. At first play through I thought “okay is this going to be awesome or what?” but the more you play it the more you discover the possibilities of outcomes that this game provides. I am impressed with the developer’s effort when they make us feel the not-so-subtle difference in our second play through. My mind was blown away.

Oh my god! I never really write Steam reviews, but I feel compelled. This game is FANTASTIC! It has a ton of suspense and excitement. I was never sure what would happen next. The story is fantastic and the characters feel real. And with different choices that affect the story in small ways and different possible outcomes, I will have to play it multiple times. Hell, I'm going to play it multiple times just for the subtle, unimportant interactions.  Would definitely recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of story-driven games. It isn't a fast-paced game, but that works well and you never really know what sort of impact your dialogue choices, or choosing to stay silent, will have later, if any at all.   My only disappointment is that it looks like I managed to get the best ending on my first go, so I regret that a little.

Oxenfree is the best story rich/puzzle games and I'll explain why. What makes this game fun is it's story where we learn about our characters and the creepy backstory of Edwards Island. Another thing what makes this game stand out to me is that it is has a 90s point and click adventure game with some puzzle elements in and that to me was what made this even more fun. Oxenfree has a puzzle solving gameplay which I think is genius by using the radio. And another thing what makes this game amazing is that every little thing you do or say it will have a result for how you complete the game. This game is perfect to play around Halloween and that is what makes it the best game. I highly recommend this game to everyone you will absoulutely love this game.
It is like reading a really really good thriller!

Loved this game. Slight bit of a drag with how slow your character runs, but that's to be expected when playing a mortal human. The story had hairs standing up on the back of my neck the whole way through, and the dialouge felt like real people.

I bought it for $11CAD and I'd say it was worth the money. This game kinda f'd me up (in a good way) tbh. But I like story-rich, walking simulator(esque) games that have good writing, that's not for everyone.

I haven't written a review in a long time, but I felt compelled after finishing this to tell everyone to pick this game up and give it a play. Don't read or watch anything about it, don't assume anything about it, just buy it, install it, and enjoy it. It's short enough that you don't feel like you're making a huge time comittment but engaging enough that you'll get sucked into it inside of the first thirty minutes. Once I got going I couldn't put it down! This was one of the most pleasant surprises I've had the pleasure of stumbling into in a long time. One of my recent favorites.

I bought this on sale. This game was not at all what I had expected, so in saying that: Oxenfree is an unexpectedly amazing game packed with chills down your spine. It is completely story based, amazing visuals, chilling soundtrack and voice acting is really well done for this, and choices DO matter in the end (bonus of receiving achievements). The characterization of this game is fantastic, the writers and the voice actors made it all too well believable.   Before getting to actually play this game I had to adjust my settings and lower the resolution because of how laggy the game was. Aside from that the controls to this game is simple and easy to follow, the only downside is not having to control when you run whenever you'd like. So often when having to walk a distance it feels more of a chore than an adventure because of how slow paced the characters are when walking. There are some areas where the pathing is really awkward but not too much of an issue.   If you're into Life Is Strange, this is definitely a game I highly recommend for you. Also gives me somewhat of a Corpse Party vibe to it. Strap yourself in for an emotional rollarcoaster. I'm not someone who's all too well for playing horror games, as much as this game freaked me out: I could not put it down. The story pulls you in with an incredible dialogue that flows naturally, and the atmosphere is stunning whilst beyond eery. It's filled with mystery, slice of life and horror. Radio frequencies have always been a creepy aspect of games and movies to me, the static sound and the inexpicable noises/voices that comes from within it. And the game focuses around that: tuning into a radio and adjusting the frequencies and running into eery audio bits from older films that loop (very often used for hints), finding a song, or hearing creepy voices. A lot of the game likes to play tricks with your mind. I would've taken my time to really look at everything, but I was honestly too creeped out by everything.  I can't say I'd probably play it again just because of the creepy aspect of it, but you never know. Overall, simply amazing.

8/10 it is a really good game  + the visuals are nice + story is solid + charaters are belivebel + multiple endings. + plot enhancing collectibles, they are not nessesary, but they are nice.  +- qte on all convesation, i'm not a fast reader so that was annoying, but it kept the flow going and me on my toes.  - I had some visual bugs with the *spoiler1* not disapering after it have been closed. - sometimes the camera is annoying. - when the *spoiler2* ask questions, you are supposed to know some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t from the start of he game that you forgot, I guess it was the point, but I did not like it. - charaters are made in 3d but everything else is 2D, it looks wierd sometimes, but only sometimes.

Within the first 10~20 minutes of the game, I knew it was going to be good. Oxenfree is amazing and excels in pretty much every aspect, and the only issues I have with the game are all very minor. It is incredibly interesting, immersive, detailed, well-paced and beautifully crafted. Here's a breakdown of everything I thought of the game, both the positives and the negatives (the former of which greatly outweighs the latter):  Pros:  - Lovely art style and animations. All of the maps are beautifully made, some especially so, and the creepy 'glitch' aesthetic for a majority of the sequences are electrifying and do a perfect job of setting the right tone for the game. - Character design and voice acting. The entire cast is unique, but not in any extreme manner that makes them unrelatable or eccentric. Their voice acting is extremely believable, life-like and strike a very nice balance of just enough dialogue to make the experience engaging, informative, and oftentimes amusing, but not to the point where you feel the characters won't shut up. - Choices and responses. Most dialogues will give you the opportunity, usually several times during one exchange, to choose between 2-3 options for Alex (the MC) to say, giving you plenty of time to develop (or destroy) your relationships and make your decisions as you see fit. The game, despite growing gradually creepier and more dire as things go, never fails to drop in something humorous or the option for it at occasional intervals, and I'm very thankful for this. - Awesome storyline! There's truly a lot of work and thought put into it, and research as well. Every aspect of the game further enhances the storyline, mainly through the use of the radio and the various signals you can tap into, some of which can offer you additional information. It's realistic while also being dystopian at the same time, and every part of the game's world (both past and present, normal and supernatural) feels 'authentic'. - Various endings and ways to get them. While I've not yet gotten them all, I know there's a good few, and I look forward to finding them all. - A balance of pacing and challenge. The game does require you to be on your toes, pay attention and act fast or remember certain things, maybe go looking around for a bit, but it is unlikely that you'll be actually 'stuck' at any point. It also balances between cinematics / extended dialogues and wandering around to explore and accomplish objectives. I never felt like I was doing too much of one thing. - One of the best things about this game: soundtrack. The sound of the whole game entire is beautiful, from the ambience, special effects, songs, recordings, and everything else. It sets various different moods across the storyline and yet not one sounds out of place. - The fact that the extra collectibles are optional. This may not seem like a big deal but to me, who doesn't usually like looking for 'every little thing' unless I actually want to, and hate feeling like I HAVE to go on a scavenger hunt, appreciates this. Especially since, as far as I know, there's nothing for it except achievements and that feeling of 'yay, I got all of them!' But I don't feel like I have to miss out on a part of the GAME for not finding these things, especially on the first playthrough.  Cons: I don't have many complaints at all about this game, but there are a few minor things.  - Movement. Some of the time I felt I wasn't moving nearly as fast as I wanted to or should. Alex would go slower at some points and faster at others, which was weird to me. Also climbing, walking on paths, going up/down inclines/declines, using stairs or bridges, etc-- all of these were a bit wonky, also slow, and sometimes you could get stuck or stop at a corner or edge. Nothing that I couldn't work around and move to make it work, but still. Movement wasn't as nice as I'd like. - Dialogue options sometimes skip if you move out of the 'play area' coded for them and moves on to the next choice. Also dialogue options have a time limit, like in Telltale's games, except it's shown in the gradual fading of the speech bubbles, and sometimes it was hard to see or know just WHEN I can no longer choose a dialogue option to respond with. Considering the player needs the time of reading the options plus considering which one is the best, I also felt some of them didn't give me enough time to decide. So I would've wanted an actual time bar + more time to choose my responses. Still, not a big issue. - Saving. The game saves automatically, normally each time to pass from one area of the map to the next, or when an important cutscene has finished. It doesn't give you the option of saving whenever you want, and several times I had to go back to the main menu and replay a segment of the game over (at one point like 5-6 times) to do exactly what I wanted and how I wanted to. So I would've appreciated a better save system, rather than having to rewind a good 5-10 minutes back and go through dialogue and walk through areas I've already done like 3 times already.   Still, I wholly enjoyed my first playthrough of the game and definitely intend on playing through more of it. It was a great experience and definitely one of my favorites of this year.  9.5/10

Even with the stunning visuals, eerie music, relatable (and hateable) characters, and a plot that changes as you make choices... Oxenfree got me hooked with the simple mechanics that ultimately drive a story for you to solve a msytery. Will you ever get out of the island? Will you escape and leave others behind? Can you really bring back the dead? With each passing approximately 4 hour run through each pass of the story, you can end up getting different results and changing what your future play through will be. How many times will you play it over to get the result you want? Get this game and find out.

The fact that a couple of scenes genuinly shocked me speaks for this game. For those who played Oxenfree I'm talking about at the visions of Clarissa and Ren. I cared about these teens.  Possibly not a game for everyone, because it's pretty slow paced and it has been called 'a walking simulator' once or twice, but if you're looking for a unique take on a horror themed teen angst story, this is the one to play.   Truly a gem of a game.  P.s. The Steam controller seems to be made for this game. Turning the radio dial with the touchpad is superb and choosing dialog option with X, Y, A and B likewise. Next to walking that sums about the gameplay of this game. :D:

This game is great in so many ways.  I originally held of playing this for... whatever reason, and I regret not getting into it faster because this game blew away my low expectations 10 minutes into the game.   Voice acting and Soundtrack.   When it comes to games like this, I.E a lot of time spent walking... and talking, voice acting is almost at the top of the pillar of importance for me. This game absolutely nailed the voice acting. It is superb. All the character have very unique and specific personalities and all the voice actors perfectly expressed it, it all felt genuine, I felt real emotion. 10/10 voice acting.  The soundtrack isn't something I absolutely loved but it was far from bad, some songs where great and the rest was just OK. It is a VHS Synth-Pop style soundtrack.   The art, graphics and controls.   The art-style of this game is very different to most, if not all games. The art mixed with the 2.5D game is a great combo. Great art direction.  Graphics are great, ran smoothly throughout my entire gameplay. Controls are also smooth, and simplistic.  This game could've easily been made into a mouse-only game or a keyboard-only game. I sorta wish they had gone with one of those, preferably mouse-only.    'Choices matter.'    There are countless amounts of games that  claim  choices made in the game matter, but just give the  illusion  of choice. Oxenfree is a true 'choices matter' game. Choices you make has impact on the game later, whether that be small flavour stuff, dialogues with characters or relationship changes. For better or worse? That's your choice.   The characters, story, emotions and gameplay.   All characters, as previously mentioned when I talked about voice acting, have their own unique personalities. Not going to spoil as to which character has what personality, I think you should discover that for yourself while playing the game. But who ever worked on the character writing did a very good job.  The story is indeed a big mystery and gets weirder and weirder the more and more you play. Has a ton of weird turns and the ending was fantastic(keep in mind there are multiple endings; I.E Choices Matter).  The game, at least with me, draws you in emotionally, whether that is negative emotions you have towards a character or positive feelings towards another. The game draws you in emotionally in many different ways at the same time. The music may perfectly fit the scenery and a major event may just have happened in the story etc...  The gameplay is not complicated but keeps you invested.   Replay-ability and a few more things.   This game has replay-ability the same way  Life is Strange  has replay-ability. You can replay the game to take a different path of choices, to discover more or complete more achievements.  This game is tagged as a horror game. It is not. It is also tagged as psychological horror, which it is. It is an ominous, Lovecraftian mystery thriller with psychological horror. It is not horror in the sense of jump scares, being chased by a boogeyman etc...  Polygon says:  A mix of freaks and geeks, Poltergeist and the best teen films of the '80s.  I wholeheartedly agree with that. This truly is an amazing combo of 80's teen supernatural movies, synth-pop music and a great cast of characters.  I really hope we see an Oxenfree 2.    Some criticism.   One of the things I disliked the most is how little time you have in  some  dialogues to reply. Not even  Life is Strange  or any of the  Walking Dead Telltale games  had such short dialogue response times in the most dire situations.  You almost always have the option to reply in a dialogue before the other character(s) are finished speaking. Most of the time that cuts of the other characters and Alex(you) start talking. Some times the other characters finish before you reply with your chosen dialogue. I wish the other characters always got to finish, instead of almost always getting interrupted by you.  The options menu is open to great improvement. Doesn't look like a lot of time or effort was put into the options menu.   Closing statement about the game.  Oxenfree truly is one of the best games I've played in 2016. Ahead of you lies a great adventure with a thrilling mystery. Great conversations with great people. Ahead of you lies a sea of emotion, suspense and choice.  I would recommend this game to anyone I know, the same way I'd recommend  the Walking Dead series  or  Life is Strange  to anyone I know. And that is a huge compliment.  Night School Studio truly put in a lot of work, love and heart into this, and they display that even more with the amount of patches they have released since Oxenfree's original release.

The gameplay is lackluster, but it's not what I took away from this game; the story in itself is worth the try, and the whole process of discovering what lurks on the island is an emotional field trip. If shows like Stranger than Fiction are up your alley, I strongly recommend giving this game a try.

I haven't played a game that stayed with me in a long while until this one. I have seriously not been this engrossed in a mystery in a long time. I wanted to know every last detail of what was happening, and every time something would happen, it was an absolute treat that I couldn't look away from. Your decisions, unlike many games, actually have significant impact and can completely change the way the characters around you act, view you, or worse. Your decisions effect how you proceed, how you may percieve the events happening around you, and even the conclusion as a whole.  9/10, would have loved for it to be a bit longer (despite the obvious intention behind the subject of replay value), but I do not feel as if I was let down or shorted out of money in the slightest. On a side note, I think that this would also make for an awesome anime. Even if we don't get a sequel or anything for Oxenfree, I will anxiously watch out for whatever DOES come next from this developer.  My best recommendation for you, the reader deciding on if they want to buy it, is this. Do you like the mystery genre? Do you want said mystery to actually consistently move forward, be multi-layered, and have substance with a satisfying conclusion? Are you okay with playing a game that doesn't involve shooting things in the face? If you answered yes to any of these, BUY OXENFREE!
I normally don't buy games in this genre but I am more than happy with this purchase. Soundtrack is perfect and ties everything together, reminds me of boards of canada.

Oxenfree is an amazing interactive story.  The game excels at creating interesting characters, and the voice acting is superb.  The dialogue is well written and filled with choices. However, it can be hard to see how your choices actually affect anything until near the end of the game.  The art style is beatiful and sticks out from the 3-D models of the characters. The art makes the game feel alive.  The game offers lots of optional exploration, but does not do a good job of providing incentive to explore.  The slow pace of movement worked well for highlighting the story, but the pace discourages backtracking for optional objectives.  These problems seem insignificant compared to what the game achieves.  This game is great for anyone looking for an interactive mystery and story game.

One of the best story-based games I've played in a while. This is what happens to games that are not screwed up in the last minute (looking at you here, Life is Strange). It is unbelievably beautiful, the story is engaging, the characters are loveable and relatable, the horror elements gives a couple thrills. The voice actors' work is just splendid. For the fans of the genre or just those who don't mind those walking/talking simulators (with, dare I say, excellent dialogue) this is a must-have.   9.5/10.

First off, this is a awesome game. Normally I'm not one to play anything in the horror genre, but this was surprisingly good. Great story line, awesome characters. Over all, a really solid game. The only downside is how quickly you can finish it. My first playthrough took about 3 hours. I will seriously be playing this again, because it has the potential for multiple endings and there is a lot more to explore than I did the first time. If you're looking for a decent game, take a chance and try Oxenfree out.

Five Word Review: Fan of adventures? Don't miss! Favorite Thing: The constant back-and-forth conversations.  + Love the art style. + A crazy, supernatural story. + Excellently voice acted.  - Speech choices are easy to miss.  Playtime: ~4h Enjoyment: 8/10
Absolute gem of a game!! Cannot recommend it enough.

What I liked:      The mystery of finding out what’s going on    The genuinely great characters and writing that engrossed me( it's all feels so natural)    Also the wierd relaxing, but also unsettling soundtrack    If you loved Stranger Things, or the Goonies or similar well written mystery “things”, you’ll love this game   What You Need to Know:      This game is played purely for the story, if you’re thinking it will have normal mechanics of puzzles or platforming look elsewhere. If you want an engrossing story that will make you care get the game     This game has choices that offer replayability, I looked up other endings and it has real impacts that make mine so bad when compared. I don’t think I’ll replay it as for me it would ruin the impact of my initial play through.     If you love mystery this game has it, it starts off with the characters and building who they are and slowly get weird and then creepy, with some sadness, then some joy and then more creepy. It’s just a well written story that I think would stand on its own against quality TV shows.     My only complaints are sometimes dialogue would get cut off by a triggered event, or my dialogue choice and they would never repeat what they were going to say. But this happened like only 3 times.     More onto the game, there are choices that matter in a lot of what you do, and how your friends react to you. I won’t spoil anything but they do have at the end comparisons to what other players did as well to gauge how awful or nice you are.( I had everyone hate, and didn’t mean to, kind of hurt me inside a little)     There are notes and radio anomalies to find out more about the story and mystery if you want. I didn’t collect them all because then it would feel less organic and more collectathon.      The mystery will pull you in to intrigue you, but like most good stories, it’s about the characters and how they respond/act to these problems, and my actions which I feel like an idiot on some of mine     They also have 40 minutes’ worth of documentaries, which I wish all games did. Because if I love a game, I want to know more about it, and the process, because I love that kind of stuff     This is what happened in my story for those who finished and what to know my outcome    My ending was happy where no one died, but everyone hated me, because I choose to sacrifice Clarissa but changed my mind. I was arguing with the ghost lady and thought I could win, which turns out I lost. Also I was so sad about what happened to Michael, he seemed like an amazing brother, and I feel so bad afterwards for realizing you could bring him back        As a game that is solely played for the story I can recommend this to everyone. It has natural sounding dialogue that makes it feel like it’s real. That to me shows great story telling in IMO    My Score:

Worth trying. One of the very few narrative-heavy games that does conversations during movement well. The dialogue is neatly written, voice acting is spot-on and the music makes a great impression. Also, the visuals are really, really good.  The decisions made during playthrough mattered more than I had initially assumed, and the epilogue wrapped things up nicely. However, I felt like the actual ending was sort of a let-down, and the story in the second half of the game wasn't as strong as the opening hours (which had three or four _really_ great scenes). Still, I implore you to try and figure out the mysteries of the island - despite the game being fairly linear there are a bunch of secrets to uncover that fill out the narrative.

I really enjoyed Oxenfree. Really great characters and story. Artwork is beautiful. Voice acting and dialogue is amazing.

Downsides: - Game is often interrupting other people's speech when you need to choose a timed dialogue option. If you wait for them to finish their sentences, you miss the dialogue choice. - There are some performance drops on even high end systems. - I had to configure Antialiasing/Multisampling via ATI graphic profile manually for smoother visuals since the game decides to use none when left alone.  Upsides: -A great story and narration -Multiple endings -Jumpscares -Nice level design which makes it easy to navigate through island   This game is a must to have...

This was undeniably well-made, with nice art and pleasant music - however, I felt that it was much more of a rather dull teenage drama than a supernatural, atmospheric thriller which is what I was informed that it would be. All of the dark and gripping aspects of the plot were very weak and I was left wanting more suspense from it.  I did not find it engaging to play at all and felt that it would have probably been better if it were an animated TV series instead of a game. The element of the player's choices affecting the storyline was ambitious, but the options given were limited and I did not really feel in control over this at all.  I was left feeling extremely dissapointed with the teen drama plot and even more dissapointed with the average educational CD-ROM style gameplay.   I am generally slow at completing games (especially ones I find engaing and atmospheric as I like to explore the entire environment) and yet I finished this in just 4 hours. I looked into how my choices could have affected the storyline in different ways, but didn't miss out on anything except for the two more difficult (but predictable) endings to come to. If I found this a more user-friendly game with a genuinely unique and gripping plot, I would definitely have replayed to see the different endings. But I did not.

I'll just start out with, this game wasn't horrible though I am a little disapointed that I wasted my time with it. The art style was enjoyable and the characters and relationships, while a little cliche, were a little more in debth than expected. Also, I always enjoy searching for series of items and there are a couple of them in this game as well as a little mystery.  However, there are a few drawbacks to the playthrough of this game. The worst is that THERE IS NO SPRINT KEY. Walking through through the map multiple times is fine by me and I like games that don't force you down a hallway, but please, PLEASE give an option to sprint. At best it is anoying, and at worst I was frustrated enough to stop playing. Given how much I enjoy getting all acheivements, I gave up on finding all the rock stacks because of this flaw.  Next is while the story is interesting and different, it is definitely predictable once you get your first few clues. I felt like they could have had a great story with the whole time loop deal and their pasts as well as going into more depth with the submarine crew. Sadly, I felt very dissapointed with the ending as it seemed cut short and it gave me no real sense of accompishment or conclusion even though I know that the ending was meant to be kinda left open.  Which brings me to my final complaint. Pretty early on, I felt like my dialoge decisions weren't makeing any difference. This definitely made the game play not as enjoyable to me. I felt like whith how the game was set up and how short it is that they could of had the decisions make more of an impact. I can only recall one point in the game in which I changed something my character was going to do otherwise. I found the the only impact that these choices did make were very superficial and more for achievments than actual story.  I had high hopes for this game and it kinda let me down. At least I bought it on sale.

If it is a book, it would be a great 'page-turner'. As a game, it kept me suspended enough to finish it in one shot. And even better, you got to choose how to plot goes.    Although I did not get Michael come back, I sort of did not regret that, it just felt like I should not keep people from doing things they want just to keep them alive, if things are to happen, it might have to happen.[/spoier]
